DOC.HEAD: Fires Claim Six Lives in Chicago
DOC.TEXT: Fires swept through apartments in several poor neighborhoods Saturday, killing six people, injuring 15 and leaving scores homeless in zero-degree weather. The dead included three young children. Fast-moving blazes trapped many people on upper floors, and at least two people jumped from a second-story window to escape flames, firefighters said. ``People were hanging out of the windows when firefighters arrived on the scene,'' Fire Department spokesman Stanley Spann said of one fire on the city's southwest side. ``They must have rescued 20 to 25 people.'' Two people were killed and 12 injured, including three critically, in that early evening blaze in a 60-unit building, Spann said. A man was killed and three people injured in a South Side fire. The three young children who were killed were trapped in their attic apartment by a fire that swept through their west side home before dawn, firefighters said. Two women, including the mother of the victims, were forced by the flames to jump from a second-story window, authorities said. Neighbors reported seeing two men running from the building shortly before the fire was discovered early Saturday, but police said their investigation turned up no evidence of arson. The fire apparently started at about 2 a.m. on an enclosed back porch and spread quickly through the rest of the house, said Battalion Chief Frank Chambers. The children, Andrew Smith, 2; Jasmine McKinney, 1, and Dominique McKinney, 3 months, were pronounced dead at the scene. Two women, identified as sisters Janet and Geraldine McKinney, escaped by jumping from a second-story window, and were both reported in fair condition. Firefighters said one was the mother of the dead children, but didn't know which one.
